articles.title: The Chinese finance whizz whose DeepSeek AI model stunned the world
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03845-4Liang Wenfeng is part of Nature’s 10, a list of people who shaped science in 2025.
articles.content:
In January this year, an announcement from China rocked the world of artificial intelligence. The firm DeepSeek released its powerful but cheap R1 model out of the blue — instantly demonstrating that the United States was not as far ahead in AI as many experts had thought.

Behind the bombshell announcement is Liang Wenfeng, a 40-year-old former financial analyst who is thought to have made millions of dollars applying AI algorithms to the stock market before using the cash in 2023 to establish DeepSeek, based in Hangzhou. Liang avoids the limelight and has given only a handful of interviews to the Chinese press (he declined a request to speak to Nature).

Liang’s models are as open as he is secretive. R1 is a ‘reasoning’ large language model (LLM) that excels at solving complex tasks — such as in mathematics and coding — by breaking them down into steps. It was the first of its kind to be released as open weight, meaning that the model can be downloaded and built on for free, so has been a boon for researchers who want to adapt algorithms to their own field. DeepSeek’s success seems to have prompted other companies in China and the United States to follow suit by releasing their own open models.

Despite R1 having many capabilities that are on a par with the best US models, including those powering ChatGPT, its training costs were much less than those of rival companies, say AI experts. Training costs for Meta’s Llama 3 405B model, for example, were more than ten times greater. DeepSeek’s bid for transparency extended to publishing the details of how it built and trained R1 when, in September, the model became the first major LLM to undergo the scrutiny of peer review (D. Guo et al. Nature 645, 633–638; 2025). By releasing its recipe, DeepSeek taught other AI researchers how to train a reasoning model.

In many ways, “DeepSeek has been hugely influential”, says Adina Yakefu, a researcher at the community AI platform Hugging Face, which is based in New York City.

The heights of AI are a far cry from the village in Guangdong province where Liang was raised as the child of two primary-school teachers. Higher education took him to the prestigious Zhejiang University in Hangzhou, where he graduated with a master’s in engineering in 2010; his thesis involved crafting algorithms to track objects in videos. He soon applied his love of AI to financial markets and, in 2015, co-founded the hedge fund High-Flyer, spinning off DeepSeek in 2023.

At that time, China faced a hurdle in developing LLMs. US export controls prevented Chinese firms from buying certain powerful computer chips known as graphics processing units (GPUs) made by the US chip manufacturer NVIDIA, which are suitable for training LLMs. But Liang was already well provisioned. He had spent the previous decade purchasing 10,000 NVIDIA GPUs, fuelled by curiosity about what research could be done on them. In a 2023 interview with Chinese media company 36Kr, he likened their purchase to someone buying a piano for their home: “One can afford it, and there’s a group eager to play music on it.”

Like many Western AI entrepreneurs, Liang has set his sights on achieving artificial general intelligence — AI systems as adept as humans in cognitive tasks — and he has shaped his company around this, says Benjamin Liu, a former researcher at DeepSeek. The company prioritizes a person’s potential over their level of experience when hiring (one author on the DeepSeek R1 paper is still in secondary school) and it operates with little hierarchy, with researchers deciding what to work on themselves. Liang is said to be closely involved in research, and “even interns like myself were treated as full-time employees with meaningful responsibilities”, says Liu.

This has broad implications for AI progress globally, beyond a niche audience, and includes detailed context on the achievement and its impact.
articles.personality_title: Chinese AI model R1 challenges global leaders with open design and low cost
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In early 2025, artificial intelligence (AI) was mostly led by big companies in the United States. Many believed they had the strongest AI models, which are computer programs that can understand and create language or solve problems.

**What happened** – In January 2025, a Chinese company called DeepSeek surprised the world by releasing a new AI model named R1. This model is special because it is powerful at solving complex tasks like math and coding, but it costs much less to make than similar US models. DeepSeek made R1 open weight, meaning anyone can download and use it for free. The company shared detailed information about how they built R1, which is unusual in the AI world. The person behind DeepSeek is Liang Wenfeng, a former financial analyst who used AI in the stock market before starting this company.

**Impact** – R1’s release showed that China can compete with US leaders in AI technology. Its low cost and open design helped many researchers worldwide who want to create or improve AI tools. This openness encourages more people to join AI research and helps spread new ideas faster. Other companies have started to release their own open AI models, inspired by DeepSeek’s approach.

**What's next step** – DeepSeek and others will likely continue working on AI that can think and learn like humans, called artificial general intelligence. The company’s way of hiring young and talented people and letting them work freely may lead to new discoveries. More AI models might become open and affordable, making AI research easier for everyone.

**One-sentence takeaway** – DeepSeek’s open and affordable AI model R1 challenges global leaders, making powerful AI technology accessible to many researchers worldwide.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le modèle d'IA R1 chinois rivalise avec les leaders mondiaux grâce à son accès libre et son faible coût
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Au début de 2025, l’intelligence artificielle (IA) était principalement dirigée par de grandes entreprises américaines, considérées comme les plus avancées dans ce domaine.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En janvier 2025, une entreprise chinoise nommée DeepSeek a surpris le monde en lançant un nouveau modèle d’IA appelé R1. Ce modèle est capable de résoudre des tâches complexes comme les mathématiques et la programmation, tout en coûtant beaucoup moins cher que les modèles américains similaires. DeepSeek a rendu R1 « open weight », ce qui signifie que tout le monde peut le télécharger et l’utiliser gratuitement. L’entreprise a partagé en détail comment elle a construit R1, ce qui est rare dans le monde de l’IA. Liang Wenfeng, ancien analyste financier, est à l’origine de cette société.

**Impact** – Le lancement de R1 montre que la Chine peut rivaliser avec les leaders américains en technologie IA. Son faible coût et son accès libre ont aidé de nombreux chercheurs dans le monde à créer ou améliorer des outils d’IA. Cette transparence encourage plus de personnes à rejoindre la recherche en IA et accélère la diffusion des nouvelles idées. D’autres entreprises ont commencé à publier leurs propres modèles ouverts, inspirées par DeepSeek.

**Prochaine étape** – DeepSeek et d’autres vont probablement continuer à développer une IA capable de penser et d’apprendre comme un humain, appelée intelligence artificielle générale. Leur méthode de recrutement de jeunes talents et de travail libre pourrait conduire à de nouvelles découvertes. Davantage de modèles d’IA pourraient devenir ouverts et abordables, facilitant la recherche pour tous.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le modèle d’IA R1 de DeepSeek, ouvert et abordable, défie les leaders mondiaux en rendant la technologie IA puissante accessible à de nombreux chercheurs dans le monde.
articles.personality_title_es: El modelo de IA chino R1 desafía a líderes globales con diseño abierto y bajo costo
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – A principios de 2025, la inteligencia artificial (IA) estaba dominada principalmente por grandes empresas de Estados Unidos, consideradas las más avanzadas en este campo.

**Qué pasó** – En enero de 2025, una empresa china llamada DeepSeek sorprendió al mundo al lanzar un nuevo modelo de IA llamado R1. Este modelo es capaz de resolver tareas complejas como matemáticas y programación, pero cuesta mucho menos que modelos similares de EE.UU. DeepSeek hizo que R1 fuera de «peso abierto», lo que significa que cualquiera puede descargarlo y usarlo gratis. La empresa compartió en detalle cómo construyeron R1, algo poco común en el mundo de la IA. Liang Wenfeng, un exanalista financiero, es la persona detrás de esta compañía.

**Impacto** – El lanzamiento de R1 mostró que China puede competir con los líderes estadounidenses en tecnología de IA. Su bajo costo y diseño abierto ayudaron a muchos investigadores en todo el mundo a crear o mejorar herramientas de IA. Esta transparencia anima a más personas a participar en la investigación y acelera la difusión de nuevas ideas. Otras empresas han empezado a lanzar sus propios modelos abiertos, inspiradas por DeepSeek.

**Próximo paso** – DeepSeek y otros probablemente seguirán trabajando en IA que pueda pensar y aprender como humanos, llamada inteligencia artificial general. La forma en que la empresa contrata jóvenes talentos y les permite trabajar libremente podría llevar a nuevos descubrimientos. Más modelos de IA podrían volverse abiertos y accesibles, facilitando la investigación para todos.

**Frase clave** – El modelo de IA R1 de DeepSeek, abierto y económico, desafía a los líderes globales al hacer accesible la tecnología poderosa de IA a muchos investigadores en todo el mundo.
